FK.content: no to-come w/out iterability, w/out heritage & possibility of repeating, w/out messianic memory and promise, messiancity more originary than all messianism, opens the worst
FK.linkedContent: no to-come w/out iterability, w/out heritage & possibility of repeating, w/out messianic memory and promise, messiancity more originary than all messianism, opens the worst

FK.content: no alliance of 2 [faith & religion], plus d’un at once more than 2: iterability, division at source > supplement introduces incalculable in heart of calculable; pure faith = pure madness
FK.linkedContent: no alliance of 2 [faith & religion], plus d’un at once more than 2: iterability, division at source > supplement introduces incalculable in heart of calculable; pure faith = pure madness

FL.content: foundation is a promise, ever positing pro-met even if promise is not kept, iterability inscribes the promise as guard in the most irruptive instant of foundation, inscribes the possibility of repetition at the heart of the originary, so there is no real distinction between preserving violence and founding, positing is always a call for preserving: differential contamination
FL.linkedContent: foundation is a promise, ever positing pro-met even if promise is not kept, iterability inscribes the promise as guard in the most irruptive instant of foundation, inscribes the possibility of repetition at the heart of the originary, so there is no real distinction between preserving violence and founding, positing is always a call for preserving: differential contamination

FL.content: revolutionary instant vs. or as exceptional decision > effaces/blurs distinction btwn founding/preserving law, inscribes iterability in originarity
FL.linkedContent: revolutionary instant vs. or as exceptional decision > effaces/blurs distinction btwn founding/preserving law, inscribes iterability in originarity

FL.content: for Benjamin, iterability precludes great founders, initiators, lawmakers (or “great” poets for Heidegger), preserves law, thus police become figure of this iterability
FL.linkedContent: for Benjamin, iterability precludes great founders, initiators, lawmakers (or “great” poets for Heidegger), preserves law, thus police become figure of this iterability

FL.content: police, index of ghostly violence, exemplary figure, figures w/out limit, w/out face or figure, not simply in uniform, a formless (gestaltlos) violence, all-pervasive specter
FL.linkedContent: police, index of ghostly violence, exemplary figure, figures w/out limit, w/out face or figure, not simply in uniform, a formless (gestaltlos) violence, all-pervasive specter

MC.content: starting w/ the stoikheia (letter, trait, number, proper name) & its marking insignificance (re-markable insignificance), Derrida explains how a mark’s supposed identity, solidity of its stereotypy, its indestructbility/indivisibility requires difference/division
MC.linkedContent: starting w/ the stoikheia (letter, trait, number, proper name) & its marking insignificance (re-markable insignificance), Derrida explains how a mark’s supposed identity, solidity of its stereotypy, its indestructbility/indivisibility requires difference/division

MC.content: ideal iterability allows every mark to withdraw from a context, in whole or in part, its insignificance allows it to continue to divide, proliferate identities, destinerring
MC.linkedContent: ideal iterability allows every mark to withdraw from a context, in whole or in part, its insignificance allows it to continue to divide, proliferate identities, destinerring

MC.content: Derrida says mark, trace rather than signifier, letter, word, or the generality of stoikheion—to extend mark beyond verbal sign, beyond human language (and beyond atomism) > thus he does not affirm “arbitrariness of sign” like Hegel, Saussure
MC.linkedContent: Derrida says mark, trace rather than signifier, letter, word, or the generality of stoikheion—to extend mark beyond verbal sign, beyond human language (and beyond atomism) > thus he does not affirm “arbitrariness of sign” like Hegel, Saussure

MC.content: “my clinamen has to do w/ the divisibility of the mark”
MC.linkedContent: “my clinamen has to do w/ the divisibility of the mark”

H.content: absolute porosity of techno-devices meant for keeping secrets, iterability that makes secrets accessible
H.linkedContent: absolute porosity of techno-devices meant for keeping secrets, iterability that makes secrets accessible

LOBL.content: starting point: “no meaning can be determined out of context, but no context permits saturation” > structure of remnant/iteration (I have said this many other ways)
LOBL.linkedContent: starting point: “no meaning can be determined out of context, but no context permits saturation” > structure of remnant/iteration (I have said this many other ways)

LOBL.content: “there is no speech act not already the iteration of another”
LOBL.linkedContent: “there is no speech act not already the iteration of another”

LOBL.content: [extensive description] yes of event, yes of iteration, quotes, cites, in accordance w/ strange ring outside of presence, sur-vives
LOBL.linkedContent: [extensive description] yes of event, yes of iteration, quotes, cites, in accordance w/ strange ring outside of presence, sur-vives

AF.content: singularity haunted by its own iterability, immanent divisibility, from the origin
AF.linkedContent: singularity haunted by its own iterability, immanent divisibility, from the origin

AF.content: faithful memory of singularity is given over to the specter
AF.linkedContent: faithful memory of singularity is given over to the specter

POO.content: iterability comes form law & contaminates singularity

SPOM.content: Marx insists on discerning, the price of the krinein of the critique: he’s out to get the specter, not the spirit, believing in a decontaminating purification, as if ghost were not haunting the spirit, as if iterability did not erase critical assurance of distinction btwn these 2 concepts
SPOM.linkedContent: Marx insists on discerning, the price of the krinein of the critique: he’s out to get the specter, not the spirit, believing in a decontaminating purification, as if ghost were not haunting the spirit, as if iterability did not erase critical assurance of distinction btwn these 2 concepts

SPOM.content: figures of death: differance of technical apparatus, iterability, non-uniqueness, prosthesis, synthetic image, simulacrum, all of which begins in language, before language
SPOM.linkedContent: figures of death: differance of technical apparatus, iterability, non-uniqueness, prosthesis, synthetic image, simulacrum, all of which begins in language, before language

SPOM.content: use-value before exchange value, hulē of wood, ordinary sensuous thing, table before dance > but it must have promised itself to iterability, no use-value w/out possibility of exchange & culture, of an hors-d’usage
SPOM.linkedContent: use-value before exchange value, hulē of wood, ordinary sensuous thing, table before dance > but it must have promised itself to iterability, no use-value w/out possibility of exchange & culture, of an hors-d’usage

SPOM.content: ghost is there [re: de-limitation of critique] in the opening of the promise, before its first apparition, from the first it will have come second, deux fois à la fois, itérabilité originaire, virtualité irréductible de cet espace et de ce temps
SPOM.linkedContent: ghost is there [re: de-limitation of critique] in the opening of the promise, before its first apparition, from the first it will have come second, deux fois à la fois, itérabilité originaire, virtualité irréductible de cet espace et de ce temps

POOF.content: priority of revealability/revelation? > iterability would give access to structure where these two poles cease to oppose each other
POOF.linkedContent: priority of revealability/revelation? > iterability would give access to structure where these two poles cease to oppose each other

POOF.content: that either address [re: omega ω] is addressed to someone will always expose utterance to undecidability because address to ‘someone’ presupposes the impossible: 1) neutral gender 2) ‘only one’ someone > for one person to receive a mark once, the mark must multiply, its iterability affirms plus d’un (which allows & limits calculability), the 3rd party is there > there is never one, one is always more than one (w/ or w/out consent)
POOF.linkedContent: that either address [re: omega ω] is addressed to someone will always expose utterance to undecidability because address to ‘someone’ presupposes the impossible: 1) neutral gender 2) ‘only one’ someone > for one person to receive a mark once, the mark must multiply, its iterability affirms plus d’un (which allows & limits calculability), the 3rd party is there > there is never one, one is always more than one (w/ or w/out consent)

SEC.content: iter (from itara, other, in Sanskrit) > everything that links otherness to repetition
SEC.linkedContent: iter (from itara, other, in Sanskrit) > everything that links otherness to repetition

SEC.content: writing not structurally legible (iterable) beyond death of addressee wouldn’t be writing
SEC.linkedContent: writing not structurally legible (iterable) beyond death of addressee wouldn’t be writing

SEC.content: no code of writing is structurally secret, can always be iterable for a 3<sup><small>rd</small></sup> party
SEC.linkedContent: no code of writing is structurally secret, can always be iterable for a 3rd party

SEC.content: no context, no code can enclose written syntagma > code: possibility/impossibility of writing, of its essential iterability (repetition/alterity)
SEC.linkedContent: no context, no code can enclose written syntagma > code: possibility/impossibility of writing, of its essential iterability (repetition/alterity)

SEC.content: isn’t iterability of writing also in speech and in all experience? > never permits unity of self-identity
SEC.linkedContent: isn’t iterability of writing also in speech and in all experience? > never permits unity of self-identity

SEC.content: identity of mark is its iterability—possibility of being repeated in absence of referent, and outside of an intention of signification
SEC.linkedContent: identity of mark is its iterability—possibility of being repeated in absence of referent, and outside of an intention of signification

SEC.content: “ritual is not an eventuality, but, as iterability, is a structural characteristic of every mark”
SEC.linkedContent: “ritual is not an eventuality, but, as iterability, is a structural characteristic of every mark”

SEC.content: Austin excludes determined modification of a general citationality, general iterability [cf. GLAS, general fetishism] w/out which no “successful” performative?
SEC.linkedContent: Austin excludes determined modification of a general citationality, general iterability [cf. GLAS, general fetishism] w/out which no “successful” performative?

SEC.content: Austin doesn’t deny iterability, “constructs a differential typology of forms of iteration” [?]
SEC.linkedContent: Austin doesn’t deny iterability, “constructs a differential typology of forms of iteration” [?]

SEC.content: could a performative not succeed if it didn’t repeat “coded” or iterable statement?
SEC.linkedContent: could a performative not succeed if it didn’t repeat “coded” or iterable statement?

SH.content: date es gibt, annulment at work when date inscribes its here and now in iterability, consigns itself to self-forgetfulness, succeeds in effacing itself
SH.linkedContent: date es gibt, annulment at work when date inscribes its here and now in iterability, consigns itself to self-forgetfulness, succeeds in effacing itself

SH.content: virtually at the same date because the originary date, as coded mark, is already a kind of fiction, singularity spoken of in generalities and fable of conventions (iterable marks)
SH.linkedContent: virtually at the same date because the originary date, as coded mark, is already a kind of fiction, singularity spoken of in generalities and fable of conventions (iterable marks)

ROP.content: iterability as condition/constitution of identity, ideality, of all concepts, but also (double bind) that which resists hierarchical and binary oppositions, a quasi-concept, inconceivable concept > not confusion, approximation, but “reaffirmed exigency of analysis”
ROP.linkedContent: iterability as condition/constitution of identity, ideality, of all concepts, but also (double bind) that which resists hierarchical and binary oppositions, a quasi-concept, inconceivable concept > not confusion, approximation, but “reaffirmed exigency of analysis”

SP.content: la signature et le texte tombent l’un hors de l’autre, se sécrètent, se séparent, et s’excrètent, se forment de la coupure même qui les décapite, les échafaude en tronc sans tête, dès l’instant de leur itérabilité > expropriative commencement marks everything erected w/ structure of etron [fecal matter]
SP.linkedContent: la signature et le texte tombent l’un hors de l’autre, se sécrètent, se séparent, et s’excrètent, se forment de la coupure même qui les décapite, les échafaude en tronc sans tête, dès l’instant de leur itérabilité > expropriative commencement marks everything erected w/ structure of etron [fecal matter]

ATIA.content: all thinkers who demand response to be human don’t think iterability essential to every response: which adds an automatic, mechanical reaction to the most alive, authentic, responsible
ATIA.linkedContent: all thinkers who demand response to be human don’t think iterability essential to every response: which adds an automatic, mechanical reaction to the most alive, authentic, responsible

ATIA.content: Derrida has problem w/ fact that Lacan’s ethics, the subject, founded on distinction btwn reaction/response > destiny of iterability: automaticity of reaction in every response
ATIA.linkedContent: Derrida has problem w/ fact that Lacan’s ethics, the subject, founded on distinction btwn reaction/response > destiny of iterability: automaticity of reaction in every response

ATIA.content: all thinkers who demand response to be human don’t think iterability essential to every response: which adds an automatic, mechanical reaction to the most alive, authentic, responsible
ATIA.linkedContent: all thinkers who demand response to be human don’t think iterability essential to every response: which adds an automatic, mechanical reaction to the most alive, authentic, responsible

SW.content: this irreducible reality of an event (outside discourse but not text)—is so unlike you? > but, it’s the signature, a hem, on the edge, forever heterogenous, a tear, overlap, remaining caught in poetic stitches—thus the effects of anticipated iterability
SW.linkedContent: this irreducible reality of an event (outside discourse but not text)—is so unlike you? > but, it’s the signature, a hem, on the edge, forever heterogenous, a tear, overlap, remaining caught in poetic stitches—thus the effects of anticipated iterability

TB.content: does a work require translation? answer is apodictic, injunction even w/out translator there, the requirement of the other as translator: structure of original, relation of life to survival > a priori, even if forgotten > its apodictic essence: it is unforgettable, so forgetting is accidental, death would not change it at all
TB.linkedContent: does a work require translation? answer is apodictic, injunction even w/out translator there, the requirement of the other as translator: structure of original, relation of life to survival > a priori, even if forgotten > its apodictic essence: it is unforgettable, so forgetting is accidental, death would not change it at all

REST.content: what if, and Derrida sees it too, they’re 2 left shoes, a double that fudges (brouille) both “pair & identity” à la fois—paralyzes directionality, fait loucher vers le diable
REST.linkedContent: what if, and Derrida sees it too, they’re 2 left shoes, a double that fudges (brouille) both “pair & identity” à la fois—paralyzes directionality, fait loucher vers le diable

REST.content: no symbolic contract in case of double that does not form a pair > not 1 (même) chose in 2, but a 2 in identity
REST.linkedContent: no symbolic contract in case of double that does not form a pair > not 1 (même) chose in 2, but a 2 in identity

PIO.content: invention’s “first time”: inaugural event and iterability > thus, no invention w/out status, w/out introduction or promise of publicity; iterability marked, remarked, at origin of invention, elle y forme une poche du premier instant: retroverted anticipation
PIO.linkedContent: invention’s “first time”: inaugural event and iterability > thus, no invention w/out status, w/out introduction or promise of publicity; iterability marked, remarked, at origin of invention, elle y forme une poche du premier instant: retroverted anticipation

PIO.content: to invent is to produce iterability & the machine for reproduction/simulation
PIO.linkedContent: to invent is to produce iterability & the machine for reproduction/simulation

TR.content: oeuvre as trace implies structure of sur-vival, what cuts the oeuvre off from the operation, cut assures archival independence, quasi-machinelike autonomy: iterability, power of repetition
TR.linkedContent: oeuvre as trace implies structure of sur-vival, what cuts the oeuvre off from the operation, cut assures archival independence, quasi-machinelike autonomy: iterability, power of repetition

TR.content: machineness (machinalité): materiality that’s not necessarily a corporeality, programming, repetition, iterability, technicity (cutting off from living subject)
TR.linkedContent: machineness (machinalité): materiality that’s not necessarily a corporeality, programming, repetition, iterability, technicity (cutting off from living subject)

WAP.content: “deconstruction is an institutional practice for which the concept of institution remains a problem” > not a critiquing or discrediting, a following of the graphics of iterability > philosophy & most vigilant practice of deconstruction share same responsibility: struggle to recognize right to philosophy & extension of philosophical teaching/research [hymen]
WAP.linkedContent: “deconstruction is an institutional practice for which the concept of institution remains a problem” > not a critiquing or discrediting, a following of the graphics of iterability > philosophy & most vigilant practice of deconstruction share same responsibility: struggle to recognize right to philosophy & extension of philosophical teaching/research [hymen]

D.content: sign becomes what it is only through possibility of its reissue (sa réédition)
D.linkedContent: sign becomes what it is only through possibility of its reissue (sa réédition)

HST.content: hôte always passing through, iterability, come, come back
HST.linkedContent: hôte always passing through, iterability, come, come back

LI.content: [re: neologism texter] signature, événement qu’on texte: process of iteration, like surnombre [of Dissemination], marks pluralization that fractures the event, the unique, while causing it to occur (arriver)
LI.linkedContent: [re: neologism texter] signature, événement qu’on texte: process of iteration, like surnombre [of Dissemination], marks pluralization that fractures the event, the unique, while causing it to occur (arriver)

LI.content: logical force of iter: ties repetition to alterity
LI.linkedContent: logical force of iter: ties repetition to alterity

LI.content: Searle explains [to Derrida] that from standpoint of iterability no difference btwn speech & writing > Derrida responds: it is so “clear,” I am so “aware,” argument was indispensable to SEC
LI.linkedContent: Searle explains [to Derrida] that from standpoint of iterability no difference btwn speech & writing > Derrida responds: it is so “clear,” I am so “aware,” argument was indispensable to SEC

LI.content: structural & essential, iterability is at work in all facts, each mark divided or multiplied in advance > a more powerful “logic”—graphics of iterability undercuts classical opposition of fact & principle (le droit), factual & possible (virtual), necessity & possibility
LI.linkedContent: structural & essential, iterability is at work in all facts, each mark divided or multiplied in advance > a more powerful “logic”—graphics of iterability undercuts classical opposition of fact & principle (le droit), factual & possible (virtual), necessity & possibility

LI.content: iterability disrupts presence, unity of ego in sender, du maintenant-écrivain (grasping w/ 1 hand his ballpoint pen) > stigmè of every mark already split
LI.linkedContent: iterability disrupts presence, unity of ego in sender, du maintenant-écrivain (grasping w/ 1 hand his ballpoint pen) > stigmè of every mark already split

LI.content: remainder (nothing in common w/ scripta manent) bound up w/ minimal possibility of re-mark & w/ structure of iterability
LI.linkedContent: remainder (nothing in common w/ scripta manent) bound up w/ minimal possibility of re-mark & w/ structure of iterability

LI.content: structure of iteration implies both identity (minimum of idealization) and difference (minimum of remainder)
LI.linkedContent: structure of iteration implies both identity (minimum of idealization) and difference (minimum of remainder)

LI.content: iterability of an element divides its own identity a priori > differential btwn & w/in elements
LI.linkedContent: iterability of an element divides its own identity a priori > differential btwn & w/in elements

LI.content: permanence depends on dialectical opposition of presence/absence > differential structure of iteration escapes this logic
LI.linkedContent: permanence depends on dialectical opposition of presence/absence > differential structure of iteration escapes this logic

LI.content: coupure intervenes moment there’s a mark, its positive condition of emergence, it is iterability itself, that which is remarkable in mark, re- of repeated, re- of repeating, condition/effect of iterability, merges w/ it, cuts across (recoupe) iterability, cutting the cut/break in remark
LI.linkedContent: coupure intervenes moment there’s a mark, its positive condition of emergence, it is iterability itself, that which is remarkable in mark, re- of repeated, re- of repeating, condition/effect of iterability, merges w/ it, cuts across (recoupe) iterability, cutting the cut/break in remark

LI.content: unity of signifying form due to its iterability, possibility of being repeated in absence of a determinate signified
LI.linkedContent: unity of signifying form due to its iterability, possibility of being repeated in absence of a determinate signified

LI.content: idealization (identity in repetition) is made possible by iterability, while broaching/breaching (entame) the idealization at once > iterability alters, contaminates, what it identifies
LI.linkedContent: idealization (identity in repetition) is made possible by iterability, while broaching/breaching (entame) the idealization at once > iterability alters, contaminates, what it identifies

LI.content: [vis-à-vis iterability altering, contaminating] no choice but to mean to say something other than what we mean to say: accident is never an accident
LI.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis iterability altering, contaminating] no choice but to mean to say something other than what we mean to say: accident is never an accident

LI.content: etymology has no value as proof: if Sanskrit itara does not mean alterity, etymology’s mistake confirms law of iterability
LI.linkedContent: etymology has no value as proof: if Sanskrit itara does not mean alterity, etymology’s mistake confirms law of iterability

LI.content: conforming to code, grammaticality, a minimum making-sense is incommensurate w/ adequate understanding of intended meaning > this incommensurability is irreducible, inheres in intention, riven (creusé) w/ iterability
LI.linkedContent: conforming to code, grammaticality, a minimum making-sense is incommensurate w/ adequate understanding of intended meaning > this incommensurability is irreducible, inheres in intention, riven (creusé) w/ iterability

LI.content: iterability can be supplemented by differance, grapheme, trace > cannot be idealized, makes idealization possible but never pure, simple: iterability has an internal impure limit, prevents it from being identified, synthesized, reappropriated by that whose iteration it entame
LI.linkedContent: iterability can be supplemented by differance, grapheme, trace > cannot be idealized, makes idealization possible but never pure, simple: iterability has an internal impure limit, prevents it from being identified, synthesized, reappropriated by that whose iteration it entame

LI.content: economics that accounts for iterability, which questions traditional philosophy of oikos, of propre—can’t be separate from economy of Unconscious, of graphematics of undecidables
LI.linkedContent: economics that accounts for iterability, which questions traditional philosophy of oikos, of propre—can’t be separate from economy of Unconscious, of graphematics of undecidables

LI.content: iterability: ruins (even ideally) the very identity it makes possible
LI.linkedContent: iterability: ruins (even ideally) the very identity it makes possible

LI.content: “from the inception on (dès l’entame) as broached and breached (entamée) in its “origin” by iterability” [re: “-bility”]
LI.linkedContent: “from the inception on (dès l’entame) as broached and breached (entamée) in its “origin” by iterability” [re: “-bility”]

LI.content: fundamental deconstructive questions necessitated by graphematics of iterability
LI.linkedContent: fundamental deconstructive questions necessitated by graphematics of iterability

LI.content: not conflating parasitism & citationality but identifying possibility they have in common [i.e. iterability] (use of or that signifies neither equivalence, dissociation, nor opposition)
LI.linkedContent: not conflating parasitism & citationality but identifying possibility they have in common [i.e. iterability] (use of or that signifies neither equivalence, dissociation, nor opposition)

LI.content: citationality not confused w/ iterability but traced back to it
LI.linkedContent: citationality not confused w/ iterability but traced back to it

LI.content: [from SEC] acc. Austin, relative purity (specificity) of each performative does not emerge in opposition to iteration or citationality but to other kinds of iteration constituted by general iterability > such iterations violate rigorous purity of every speech act (event of discourse)
LI.linkedContent: [from SEC] acc. Austin, relative purity (specificity) of each performative does not emerge in opposition to iteration or citationality but to other kinds of iteration constituted by general iterability > such iterations violate rigorous purity of every speech act (event of discourse)

LI.content: iterability displaces dividing-line btwn opposition nature/convention
LI.linkedContent: iterability displaces dividing-line btwn opposition nature/convention

LI.content: iterability doesn’t limit intentionality in general but its consciousness, its presence to itself
LI.linkedContent: iterability doesn’t limit intentionality in general but its consciousness, its presence to itself

LI.content: iterability at once condition/limit of mastery: entame it
LI.linkedContent: iterability at once condition/limit of mastery: entame it

LI.content: all concepts appeal to idealization, even “concept” of iterability > but it has a strange status: marks possibility/limit of idealization, thus conceptualization too
LI.linkedContent: all concepts appeal to idealization, even “concept” of iterability > but it has a strange status: marks possibility/limit of idealization, thus conceptualization too

LI.content: alogical logic of iterability: it’s an ideal concept, but also the one that marks essential & ideal limit of all pure idealization > not the concept of nonideality
LI.linkedContent: alogical logic of iterability: it’s an ideal concept, but also the one that marks essential & ideal limit of all pure idealization > not the concept of nonideality

LI.content: repeatability of both (identificatory) iterability & (altering) iterability > necessity of thinking rule & event, concept & singularity, at once
LI.linkedContent: repeatability of both (identificatory) iterability & (altering) iterability > necessity of thinking rule & event, concept & singularity, at once

LI.content: iterability thus a concept that renders possible the silhouette of ideality, & hence the concept, hence all distinction > marks the limit of idealization/conceptualization: “concept” or quasiconcept of concept in its conceptualizable relation to nonconcept
LI.linkedContent: iterability thus a concept that renders possible the silhouette of ideality, & hence the concept, hence all distinction > marks the limit of idealization/conceptualization: “concept” or quasiconcept of concept in its conceptualizable relation to nonconcept

LI.content: margin, parasite, iterability belong w/out belonging to the class of concepts of which they must render an accounting—to theoretical space they organize in a “quasi”-transcendental manner: something happens by or to set theory > all this must be rendered (rendre compte et raison) by us enlightened modern thinkers, right?
LI.linkedContent: margin, parasite, iterability belong w/out belonging to the class of concepts of which they must render an accounting—to theoretical space they organize in a “quasi”-transcendental manner: something happens by or to set theory > all this must be rendered (rendre compte et raison) by us enlightened modern thinkers, right?

LI.content: repeatability of same ensures that full presence of a singularity, in being repeated, references something else, thus rending the full presence it announces
LI.linkedContent: repeatability of same ensures that full presence of a singularity, in being repeated, references something else, thus rending the full presence it announces

LI.content: this something else is why iteration is different from simple repetition
LI.linkedContent: this something else is why iteration is different from simple repetition

LI.content: iterability not merely a law of intentionality, though it introduces the structural limit of its telos > Derrida distrusts figure of intention, which grows increasingly obscure [Derrida not in “conflict” w/ intentionality, just observes limit to its telos > intentionality no more telos than arché]
LI.linkedContent: iterability not merely a law of intentionality, though it introduces the structural limit of its telos > Derrida distrusts figure of intention, which grows increasingly obscure [Derrida not in “conflict” w/ intentionality, just observes limit to its telos > intentionality no more telos than arché]

LI.content: deconstruction of onto-theological humanism (of Heidegger too) > iterability of mark beyond all human speech acts
LI.linkedContent: deconstruction of onto-theological humanism (of Heidegger too) > iterability of mark beyond all human speech acts

TN.content: Levinas, by way of Husserl, proposes the word sentance to describe an immediate iteration “whose sensation is the event itself”
TN.linkedContent: Levinas, by way of Husserl, proposes the word sentance to describe an immediate iteration “whose sensation is the event itself”

AD.content: election not restricted to particular place/identity, inseparable from what seems to contest it: substitution
AD.linkedContent: election not restricted to particular place/identity, inseparable from what seems to contest it: substitution

AD.content: iterability: replaceability of unique in experience of unicity [see p. 72]
AD.linkedContent: iterability: replaceability of unique in experience of unicity [see p. 72]

OG.content: trait permits imitation, donner lieu to art as mimesis, possibility of iteration, this life & death of art > technique & imitation: opens space of calculation (grammaticality, scientific intervals)
OG.linkedContent: trait permits imitation, donner lieu to art as mimesis, possibility of iteration, this life & death of art > technique & imitation: opens space of calculation (grammaticality, scientific intervals)
